SENT.plain: The tendency of isolated germinal center (GC) B cells to undergo apoptosis was suppressed by recombinant cell-bound CD40 ligand (CD40L): after 2 days at 37 degrees C, > 80% of cells remained viable in the presence of CD40L as compared to < 1% in control cultures
CD40L sustained a high rate of DNA synthesis in GC cells and was more effective than monoclonal antibody to CD40 in this regard
Group I Burkitt lymphoma (BL) cell lines induced to undergo apoptosis with anti-immunoglobulin or calcium ionophore were also protected by CD40L
In BL cells, this route of rescue was not accompanied by induction of Bc1-2 protein, the expression of which has been linked to hemopoietic cell survival
Bc1-2 was induced in GC cells responding to CD40L, but its appearance was a relatively late event not reaching significant levels over controls until day 2 of culture
Thus induction of Bc1-2 appears to be secondary to the survival signal imparted by CD40L

These findings are discussed in relation to a potential role for CD40L in supporting B cell tumors in vivo and the discovery that the molecular defect in the X-linked Hyper-IgM syndrome is targeted to the CD40L gene
